bestBHT.bht: Though many boast in their worldly achievements, the speaker also chooses to boast according to the flesh, not to elevate himself, but to demonstrate his equality with false teachers. While these earthly accolades are not his desired source of boasting, he acknowledges them to affirm his worthiness. By highlighting his sufferings, he shows that even in the realm of the flesh, he surpasses these false apostles who rely on their Jewish heritage. His aim is to secure valuable ends and maintain his rightful place among the Corinthians.

Henry Alford: Since many...boast according to the flesh...I also will boast (according to the flesh).
Having regard to their extraction, achievements, &c.
He is here speaking as 'one of the foolish ones.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I will glory also—that is, I also will boast of such fleshly advantages, to show you that even in these I am not their inferiors.
Therefore ought not to be supplanted by them in your esteem though these are not what I desire to glory in.
Albert Barnes: Seeing that many glory ... - The false teachers in Corinth. They boasted of their birth, rank, natural endowments, eloquence, etc.
I will glory also - I also will boast of my endowments, which though somewhat different yet pertain in the main to the 'flesh' also.

His endowments 'in the flesh,' or what he had to boast of pertaining to the flesh, related not so much to birth and rank, though not inferior to them in these, but to what the flesh had endured - to stripes and imprisonments, and hunger and peril.
John Calvin: Should any one say to me, by way of objection, that what I do is faulty, what then as to others? Are not they my leaders?
Why should that be reckoned praiseworthy in them, that is imputed to me as a fault?
To glory after the flesh, is to boast one’s self, rather in what has a tendency towards show, than in a good conscience.
Archibald T. Robertson: After the flesh (κατα σαρκα). It is κατα σαρκα not κατα Κυριον.
I also (καγω). But he knows that it is a bit of foolishness and not like Christ.
John Gill: Many glory after the flesh... of which the false apostles, being Jews, boasted, who it seems were many.
He might be allowed to boast also of such like things, so far as he could with truth and a good conscience, and in order to secure some valuable ends.
He gloried of these, and of others besides them, which the false apostles could not, and thereby proved himself to be superior to them, even in external things, of which they bragged so much.
John Wesley: After the flesh — That is, in external things.

bhtAttempts.bht: Although many boast according to their worldly achievements, the speaker declares that he also will boast according to the flesh. This boast is not to elevate himself over others, but rather to demonstrate that even in these earthly advantages he is not inferior to false teachers who have infiltrated the community. While these fleshly accolades are not what he desires to boast in, he acknowledges them as a means to affirm his worthiness in the eyes of the Corinthians. By highlighting his sufferings and hardships, he shows that even in the realm of the flesh, he surpasses these false apostles who rely on their Jewish heritage for worth. Ultimately, his intent is to secure valuable ends and maintain his rightful place among the Corinthians.

Though many boast in their worldly achievements, the speaker also chooses to boast according to the flesh, not to elevate himself, but to demonstrate his equality with false teachers. While these earthly accolades are not his desired source of boasting, he acknowledges them to affirm his worthiness. By highlighting his sufferings, he shows that even in the realm of the flesh, he surpasses these false apostles who rely on their Jewish heritage. His aim is to secure valuable ends and maintain his rightful place among the Corinthians.

Though many boast according to the flesh, the speaker declares that he will also boast in such worldly accomplishments. However, he emphasizes that this is not his desired form of boasting, but rather a means to show equality with false teachers. Highlighting his sufferings and hardships, he demonstrates his superiority to those who rely solely on their Jewish heritage. By doing so, he aims to secure valuable ends and maintain his rightful place among the Corinthians.

Boasting in earthly achievements, the speaker reveals his intention to commend himself, not to elevate above others, but to emphasize his equality with false teachers. While these fleshly accolades are not his desired source of boasting, he acknowledges them as a means to affirm his worthiness. By highlighting his afflictions and challenges, he demonstrates his superiority over those who rely solely on their Jewish heritage. This approach allows him to secure important goals and maintain his rightful position among the Corinthians.

While many boast according to worldly achievements, the speaker also chooses to boast in such earthly matters. However, he clarifies that this is not his desired form of boasting but rather a means to demonstrate his equality with false teachers. By emphasizing his sufferings and hardships, he establishes his superiority over those who rely solely on their Jewish heritage. Through this approach, he strives to achieve important objectives and maintain his rightful position within the Corinthians' community.
